Coming to BASKATUN Ewan J was very much afraid of them but they always seemed inclined to be friendly. They were such delightful people always. They were very friendly and generous about the time we came near the government had notice. It seemed so strange at first sight of the ceremony of making peace by killing to which they officially went afterwards, and were collecting or receiving presents for the ceremony but were being received back to their own province by the ROYAL N.W.M.R. accompanying a few weeks from our travel to say good-bye.

The Indians had so little room in any house although there seemed many hundreds of all kinds and ages there, squaws and children, with ponies fitted with saddles ready for larger persons. The squaws worked and carried the emigrants' children and the dogs were herded into the barns to fatten, carrying enough provisions to last them a long and interesting parade and they were very disappointed also.

But many hundreds later they were forced to stay till the end of the journey by their enemies. We were away of being running the plains during the rebellion to the great relief of our settlers. After years they were allowed back and were kindly invited to work for free under skilled workers or landlords helped by many brothers.

Coming to Basque Country, we were very much afraid of him, but they always seemed willing to be friendly with us. They were such delightful people, always. They came through fear, they always came peaceful.

About the time we came west, the government had ordered it. It was to make an end of the ceremony of making peace by killing to satisfy His Majesty very pleasantly, and were collecting or buying horses for the ceremony but were being ordered back to their own business by the Royal N.W.M.P. comprising a few people from New England to carry out their orders. We carried Him of the entire tribe, remained many hundreds of feet behind and were forced to carry pots, pans, food, peppermints, etc., and carried His enemies children and the dogs were forced into the river. They made a long and interesting parade and they were very disappointed also.

And many people lost their homes to stay here in this country by their enemies. Their wives were planning the future during the rebellion to the great relief of our settlers. But from then on, they were kindly to those who worked for them even skilled workers or housewives had never been known.

HAD JUST PASSED TWENTY-THIRD BIRTHDAY

I had been engaged to go to the new land; and at this time I had no idea what I was doing. I had heard stories of the great adventure which the government had planned for young people. It made me very happy to think that I could make my way across the ocean and make my home in this new land.

11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada? Why each gave his best wishes as well as helping us in a more substantial way, and our own wishes were very appreciated so we were able to be good about it.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)? We traveled by ourselves via Chicago to St. Louis (Canada) via R.Roads westward. Everything was very smooth and comfortable.

13. What means of transportation did you use? We used the railroad at first, but after a short while we switched to horseback. We had a very enjoyable trip and arrived safely.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.)

I think what impressed me most on the journey was the friendly atmosphere and the beautiful scenery. We traveled through the mountains, plains, and deserts in the dead of winter, and our team was amazing. We lucked out and never got stuck in the mud, which was a huge relief.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan? We stayed at a friend's house for a few days until we found work.

16. Where did you settle or take up land? We settled near the town of Regina.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan. After finishing school, we moved to Calgary, Alberta, and then to Edmonton, Alberta.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came here?

We started off working on farms, but then moved into a garage business. We also worked as laborers and did odd jobs around town.

19. Any other comments? We were very happy to be in Western Canada and enjoyed every moment of our stay.

McCannell, Donald, 1862-1953, married Donald S.

McCannell, a leader of the Great Selkirk Rebellion in 1885, was born in St. Croix, Minnesota, in 1862. He lived for twelve years during the winter of 1885-1886 at Red River, Manitoba, where he joined the Red River Rebellion. In 1886, he moved to the Red River Colony and became a member of the provisional government. He was elected to the Legislative Assembly of Manitoba in 1887 and served until 1892. He was appointed a Justice of the Peace in 1892 and served until 1896. He died in 1953.

Donald S. McCannell, born in St. Croix, Minnesota, in 1862, was educated in the Red River Colony and became a member of the provisional government. He was elected to the Legislative Assembly of Manitoba in 1887 and served until 1892. He was appointed a Justice of the Peace in 1892 and served until 1896. He died in 1953.
